display_asset.caption: Adnan Syed in an undated photograph provided by his brother, Yusuf.

summaries.body: A judge on Friday will conclude a hearing to determine whether there will be a retrial for Adnan Syed, whose 2000 murder conviction was the premise of the "Serial" podcast.

display_asset.caption: “Bust of a Woman” (1931), whose ownership is being disputed, is part of an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
display_asset.credit: 2016 Estate of Pablo Picasso/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York, Philip Greenberg for The New York Times

summaries.body: Leon D. Black, the co-chairman of the Museum of Modern Art, was revealed to be the prospective buyer of a Picasso statue at the center of an ownership dispute between an art dealer and the Qatar royal family.

display_asset.caption: Matt LeBlanc on an episode of “Friends” in 1999.

summaries.body: The actor Matt LeBlanc, who played Joey on "Friends," will become the first American to co-host the popular car-themed show "Top Gear" on the BBC.
An American tourist has found celebrity in Iceland after he typed the wrong address into his rental car's GPS and drove six hours before realizing his mistake.

display_asset.caption: South Korean soldiers patrolling the border with North Korea. Both countries have escalated their propaganda war across the heavily armed border since the North’s latest nuclear test.

summaries.body: In an escalating propaganda war, North Korea has begun sending balloons into South Korea that are filled with cigarette butts.
The parents of Etan Patz say they believe a bodega worker killed their son in 1979, and have asked a civil court to overturn a 2004 ruling that another man was responsible.

display_asset.caption: A staged mass wedding in Shanghai, part of a matchmaking event to inspire singles to marry. Young Chinese can feel enormous pressure from their families to settle down, especially when relatives assemble for the Lunar New Year.

summaries.body: A group of friends in China, tired of the social pressure to marry, have paid for an ad extolling singlehood. The ad went up on Thursday at a busy subway station in Beijing.

display_asset.caption: Satellite imagery dated Jan. 25, 2016, showed three objects at the base of the gantry tower that were either vehicles or equipment at the Tongchang-ri launch site in North Korea.

summaries.body: Increased vehicle activity at a site near North Korea's border with China could be a sign of preparations for a rocket launch, according to a website that monitors the North.
A study suggests that women who watch rom-coms are more likely to accept male aggression and obsessiveness.

display_asset.caption: A stuffed mammoth excavated from ice in Siberia, and a skeleton of a giant ground sloth. Researchers say neither was on the menu at the annual Explorers Club dinner in 1951, despite what diners might have believed.
display_asset.credit: Left: Hulton Archive/Getty Images; Right: Universal History Archive, via UIG, via Getty Images

summaries.body: A 1950s club of explorers was said to have served its members mammoth at a now-legendary dinner, but DNA tests have revealed what the meat really was.
Black students were half as likely as their white peers to be placed in programs for gifted students, a new study has found.
A day after saying that Amazon planned to open 300 to 400 brick-and-mortar bookstores, a shopping mall executive stepped back from his comments.

display_asset.caption: The C.D.C.’s suggestion of indefinite sobriety did not sit well with some women.
display_asset.credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

summaries.body: The C.D.C. recommended that sexually active women steer clear of alcohol to avoid the risk of giving birth to babies with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders.

display_asset.caption: The filming of the new music video “Chaika” by the Russian punk protest group Pussy Riot.

summaries.body: The Russian punk group Pussy Riot sashayed back into the public eye with a rap video alleging corruption by the prosecutor who locked up members of the group in 2012.

display_asset.caption: Charred vehicles at a checkpoint in a residential neighborhood of Homs, Syria.
display_asset.credit: Syrian Arab News Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: A video taken by a drone winding its way through the battered Syrian city of Homs contains haunting images of the destruction after five years of civil war.

display_asset.caption: Benoît Violier in 2012.

summaries.body: The star French-Swiss chef Benoît Violier gave no indication of distress in a newspaper interview days before his apparent suicide.

display_asset.caption: Amaury Villalobos and William Vasquez reacted after their exonerations in a 1980 Brooklyn arson case. From left, Adele Bernhard, a lawyer, with Mr. Villalobos; Rita Dave, a lawyer, with Mr. Vasquez; and the widow of Raymond Mora, a third defendant who was cleared, Janet Mora, and their daughter, Eileen Mora.
display_asset.credit: Pearl Gabel for The New York Times

summaries.body: A record 149 inmates were found in 2015 to have been falsely convicted, part of a rising trend, a report found.

display_asset.caption: Mr. Jones, 72, was convicted along with another man of killing a store manager in 1979.
display_asset.credit: Georgia Department of Corrections, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

summaries.body: Georgia’s oldest death row inmate has been executed. Brandon Astor Jones, 72, was put to death for a 1979 murder. The Supreme Court declined to grant a stay of the execution.

display_asset.caption: Lord Lucan on his wedding day in 1963.

summaries.body: A London court issued a death certificate for Lord Lucan, an earl who disappeared after the killing of his family’s nanny in 1974. The decision allows his son to inherit the title.

display_asset.caption: Darnell Earley
display_asset.credit: Zack Wittman/The Flint Journal, via Associated Press

summaries.body: The manager of the Detroit Public Schools, who had also managed the city of Flint, Mich., and oversaw its decision to draw its water from the Flint River, resigned.

display_asset.caption: The steering wheel in the 2006 Ford Ranger belonging to Joel Knight. He was killed in December when the vehicle’s Takata airbag ruptured after he ran into a stray cow in South Carolina.

summaries.body: Senators Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut and Edward Markey of Massachusetts urged the Obama administration to significantly expand the recall of Takata airbags.
People in Oregon are the fastest talkers in the country, according to a new analysis of more than four million phone calls.

display_asset.caption: Molly Neuman, a veteran of the indie music scene who is Kickstarter’s head of music, at the company’s headquarters in Brooklyn.

summaries.body: Kickstarter and other crowdfunding sites have moved beyond indie music and become part of the financial circuit for artists of all types, including four Grammy nominees.

display_asset.credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images, left; and Randy Holmes/ABC

summaries.body: A reporter writes that there is no love lost between Megyn Kelly and Bill O’Reilly, and that their mutual dislike is “an open secret in the halls of Fox.”
The editor of the news website The Intercept said a reporter had made up quotations and impersonated sources. It is retracting one article and correcting four.

display_asset.caption: A picture provided by Amnesty International of Ashraf Fayadh.

summaries.body: Ashraf Fayadh, a stateless poet who was convicted of apostasy by a Saudi court, had his death sentence reduced to eight years in prison and 800 lashes.

display_asset.caption: The Browns said Johnny Manziel “undermines the hard work of his teammates and the reputation of our organization” with his off-field actions.

summaries.body: Two years after drafting him, the Browns look ready to give up on Johnny Manziel. The team issued a statement after Manziel’s latest incident implying it would cut him.

display_asset.caption: In 2003, animal and elephant welfare groups opposed a plan to move 11 elephants from this group in Swaziland to the United States.

summaries.body: The plane transfer of 18 elephants from Swaziland to America is being criticized by conservationists. But the U.S. wildlife service said it would save them from being culled.

display_asset.caption: The Milwaukee Bucks guard Rashad Vaughn, left, blocks the shot of the Sacramento Kings guard Rajon Rondo during a basketball game in Sacramento on Monday. Giveaway T-shirts were pulled the same day.

summaries.body: The Sacramento Kings pulled "Year of the Monkey" shirts from seats after complaints that the Lunar New Year giveaway, in Black History Month, was racially insensitive.

display_asset.caption: Tata said it would rename its new hatchback.

summaries.body: Zica, a new hatchback unveiled by the Indian automaker Tata Motors late last year, is to be re-branded because of the Zika virus public health emergency.
